review_text: We loved staying at Gabe & Hayden's place. This was our 34th anniversary, and wanted a peaceful getaway. They are located on a shady street, where I enjoyed morning walks. This street didn't have a lot of traffic, yet it was so close to the things we were interested in seeing/doing. We decided to walk to a local grocery store, too, which was only about a 10-15 minute walk. We had thought to bring a cooler bag to bring items home in. The walk was especially nice due to the beautiful homes on Lafayette Street (picture New Orleans)! Saturday morning, we went to the Farmer's Market - a 5-minute drive (I think). This is one of the best Farmer's Markets I've experienced - 3 street musicians playing on the corners of the square! We bought fresh veggies to bring home and cook. Gabe & Hayden have a good amount of cookware, a nice gas stove, a darling "vintage-like" fridge, knives, oils, spices, vinegar. We brought our Foodi (Ninja's version of the Instapot) to use, too. But, we hardly needed it. The beds/bedding were super comfortable, the internet was FAST, the smart TV was available, and they have a very nice shower. In the room with the king-sized beds, I think they might have black-out curtains because the room was nice and dark. My husband and I both especially loved how they decorated their bathroom! A couple of other Fayetteville happenings we enjoyed were the Walton Arts Center to see a broadway musical and the public library is BIG with covered parking and a deli (also 5-10 minute drive). We would definitely enjoy a return trip here.

If you’re familiar with the award-winning architect Fay Jones, then you won’t need any convincing to stay at this beautifully restored mid-century modern. If you’re not, this is your chance to learn more and experience the best of the 1950s with all the conveniences of today (especially better bathrooms). Jones was an apprentice to Frank Lloyd Wright and the house is unique in reflecting Usonian (US) design characteristics. The property is expansive, with an upper terrace that stretches into the trees and offers a lovely view of city lights at night.
The home is very convenient to the University of Arkansas yet feels miles away. The McKees are delightful to work with and we had the good fortune to meet David McKee, a Jones’ apprentice and the force behind restoring Fay on Gray, and his lovely wife Alice. Would happily stay again, only longer!
